title: TI-Unit
subtitle: C++ Testing Framework for the TI-84 Graphing Calculator

lines: TI-Unit is a developer tool which brings unit testing to the TI-84 graphing calculator.
I have always enjoyed building games and applications for the TI-84, but often struggled with testing my code in such a niche embedded environment.
So, I decided to build my own framework which standardizes how tests are defined in code and executed on the calculator.

body.description: A selection of user defined tests.

lines: The project allows the user to define standalone tests or groups of tests known as suites.
Inside a test, the user can perform assertions and log information.
All results are stored in memory.
The bulk of TI-Unit is its native UI.
The various provided menus and text panes allow the user to easily execute tests and read output.
I have written testing software for normal computers before.
However, TI-Unit runs in an embedded environment on a non-standard operating system.
I had very little memory at my disposal and no access to common mechanisms like threads or processes.
Working around these constraints was the most challenging part of the project.
To prevent memory exhaustion, I gave the user the ability to manually recycle individual test results.
Additionally, I used the long jump system call to simulate test exceptions.

lines: The framework resides in the C++ section of my TI-84 repo linked above.
To see example tests, investigate the UI library.
All components and algorithms used in the UI are themselves tested by the framework.
